title: Water companies failing to pass on financial gains, claims...
text:
By Western Morning News | Posted: October 14, 2015 By Kate Langston Water companies failing to pass on financial gains, claims spending watchdog X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Water companies are failing to pass on financial gains to their customers, according to a new report by the government spending watchdog, with households in the South West receiving the highest bills despite subsidies. 
The study also reveals prices have increased by 40% in real terms since the sector was privatised more than 20 years ago, with water bills accounting for up to 5% of spending in the country’s poorest homes. 
The findings from the National Audit Office’s (NAO) investigation into regulation of the water sector have met with concern from members of the Public Accounts Committee, who say the number of people struggling to afford bills is on the rise. 
But the NAO says the situation looks to be improving, with companies improving the quality of their services and regulators increasing customer value for money. 
According to the report, water suppliers made net windfall gains of at least £800 million between 2010 and 2015 – largely as a result of lower than expected corporation tax and interest rates. 
In the 26 years since the industry was privatised, the study shows water prices have increased by 40% in real terms, accounting for 2.3% of average household spending in 2013, and rising to over 5% for the poorest households. 
Customers supplied by South West Water currently receive the highest bills out of any UK region, paying an average of £495 a year despite the Government’s recent introduction of a £50 annual subsidy. 
This rate is also in spite of firms absorbing costs and providing water bill discounts worth up to £435 million. 
Assessing the economic regulation of the sector in light of these figures, NAO boss Amyas Morse has warned consumers are “not enjoying enough of the benefits” of suppliers’“unexpected financial gains”. She also claimed that while Government departments have overseen “major improvements” in water and service quality in recent years, industry regulator Ofwat still has work to do to achieve customer value for money. 
Her views have been echoed by public accounts chairman Meg Hillier who described companies’ efforts to reduce costs tohouseholds as “encouraging”, but warned the number of customers who would need help to pay their bills was set to rise. 
“I am concerned that in recent years higher water bills and falling incomes have meant that water has become less affordable, and those who can least afford it appear to have been worst affected,” she said. 
“Water is a basic human necessity and most taxpayers are unable to choose their supplier. 
“It is encouraging that most water companies have set up schemes to support those who struggle to afford to pay their bills and allow them to pay a reduced rate. But it is worrying that 1.8 million households are expected to need this support by 2020. 
“More work is clearly needed to ensure customers share in savings made by water companies and there may be lessons which can be learnt from regulators in other highly regulated industries.”
